note.title: why I wanted to be an entrepreneur

notes.note: I saw myself as a leader, responsible for several thousand employees. I wanted to be someone who would enable them to live a life of blessings. That they would have a voice and be proud of the company they worked for. To me An entrepreneur is someone that creates something that previously wasn't there: jobs, meaning, provision for their family.

I must confess that my initial thoughts about MBA were just to shore up a few issues in my business. However, as i am in my DU courses i realized that not all MBA's are equal. This is an obvious statement to you Harvard, but to experience a great, but not top organization. I now see and appreciate a low acceptance rate. I am applying to schools, preparing for the GMAT, writing essays, getting my Masters, running my own business, caring for our two month old, and still trying to work on my romance skills for my wife who is the most important person in my life. Since I have already been accepted to DU's MBA program, I have nothing to loose to reach to the highest possible level.

On the day my son was born our house was robbed. I spent house with the police filing a report and them covering our apartment in red dust. On my way back to the hospital I received a call that a $40,000 sale due the next day had gone missing.
_An MBA by any other school would not be as sweet._

The type of company I'm going to run is not a simple bottom line, but a triple bottom line where people, profits, and the environment are considered. Mankind is able to do all kinds of luxaries we weren't not privy to prior the internet. Now with this new set of wisdom and understanding we are able to do more with less.

I am always in the mood to read. It just depends on what mood will depend what type of reading. I'm usually reading 5 - 7 books at a time covering all topics. On my latest attempt : magice of thinking big,...

After my first business ended, I began doing all kinds of searching for the next thing. My ideas for businesses ranged from starting a burrito franchise to developing a social networking site based on goal setting. After a while of intensive brainstorming, I started to wonder why these ideas were not taking root or lasting beyond a month. I started to consider what were some core ingredients necessary to run a successful busienss. My conclusion was that it needed to possess at least 3 parts for it to gain some traction: 1. There needs to be a need - business is to difficult if you have to regularly educate your customers why they need your service. 2. You need to be able to meet this need with a natural resourse. The example I use is that a local californian can make a calendar with beach photos a lot cheaper than I can based in Denver. FInding a natural resourse that most people would take for granted locally. 3. You need a scientist. someone who was passionate about the production and operations to turn your raw resourse into a product worth selling. AMB3R actually met all 3 criteria unlike any idea I had before. I decided to give it a try and fortunately we have experienced some solid success. We started with $5,000 and are looking to do $500,000 our first year in sales with an average gross profit margin of 30%.

I love having options. I am like a gardener where I would rather have abundance than scarecity. If I were to continue on my path with AMB3R, we would work toward creating a new and unique retail environment called a Design Studio. This retail concept is in the same philosophy of what Starbucks did with Coffee and Cold Stone did with Ice Cream. They turned normal commodities into an experience. I would like to make a retail concept that is a special receipie of 4 retail stores - Starbucks, Kinkos, Anthropologie, and Apple. This retail environment would be a design experience for people to learn and feel all the various options they have in their apparel production for their tees for their church, camp, band, school, non-profit, and more.

note.title: If I had only 5 books on an island:

notes.note: Review 1. - cxc tour 2. - retail 3. - dvd 4. - kiosk 5. - Putting out 6 tee shirt lines of 4 - 10 designs per line. 6. - Tradeshow promotions - YS 7. - Building and Managing a street team of 300 youth -- "how i wrestle with difficult decisioins" We learned the tradeshow circuit and were able to successfully get into 100 stores by our own display and presentation. The challenge was that we were really great at selling to the people in front of us, but they were not able to sell as well as we were. We saw that a youth even would sell 1000 - 1200 shirts in one weekend so we knew the kids liked our product. The challege was how should we do that... We took a risk on a kiosk. We believed that was our opportunity. However we failed to realize that the wholesale and retail models are two different beasts and we should have realized that with our accounting methods.

My choice was to make my own path so that I could be exposed to every aspect of a successful company. There is a substantial overlap of educational experience when you're in the drivers seat and nothing happens without your action. however, I am ready to enter the the larger businesses.

in my undergrad i acquired the nickname "ABD" which stood for All Business Dave. I became known to my peers based on, what I believe, two different referance points. First, I started a teeshirt company that was based on my local environment enabling me to see almost 5,000 tees out of my dorm room and back of my trooper. I had developed this reputation enough to start a nice side business for myself by making other peoples tees for their band or church event. The other reason I feel I got my nickname was if I wasn't peddlng cotton, I was trying to recruit my close friends to some sort of challenge, event, game, or contest. I was regularly coming up with "Micro clubs" based on an activity for a short period, then recruiting anyone and everyone who would listen. The list includes: Eating contests (Example: Sixty Chicken McNuggets in Sixty Minutes), Ping pong, music clubs, snowboarding and mountain biking events, and road trips to cape hatters for a quick surf session. Thank fully I almost had my thumb cut off. I escaped with received 13 stitches. It was the wake up call i needed to realize that if i don't get my head on straight and return back to school. The first half of my undergrad was needless to say not very academic focused and my grades demonstrate that. I did take a year off school to work at Sports life... then returning... 3.6...

I've been passionate the apparel business for 12 years. I started 2 companies and worked at another. The problem is nobody needs another tee shirt. we all have dresser drawers stuffed with them. Additionally, if you wanted to print one, you can get one practically anywhere. My challenge is building a business in a competitive commodity market. How we've done that is focus on the creative component and the user's experience. I have a vision to create a retail concept that would be the kinkos for apparel in an environment that is like Mac meets anthropologie. I want to run the next quiksilver.

1. Describe your career goals: short term (while you pursue an MBA), post-MBA (immediately following), and long-term (10-15 years out)? Why have you selected the Kellogg School to assist you in accomplishing these goals? (500-600 words) 2. Why are you interested in pursuing your MBA while continuing to work full time? Why have you selected the Saturday MBA program and what do you feel you can contribute to it? (500 to 750 words) 3. Please respond to two of the following (750 words maximum each): a) If you had to choose three people, alive or from another era, to travel with you on a car trip across the country, who would you choose and why? b) You have just completed your 300 page autobiography. Please submit page 197. c) If you could wake up tomorrow with one new ability or quality, what would it be and why? 4. OPTIONAL: Is there a component of your application that you would like to address to the Admissions Committee? (250 words maximum)

note.title: people, causes, and organizations I've been involved with

notes.note: World Vision, Sports Life Kanakuk Above and Beyond GIVE South Palm Beach Community Church - Summer Camp HAITI organization - orphanage in haiti

note.title: innovation and GLobal supply chain... ALSO - Idea i've defended?

notes.note: The entrepreneur in me wants to be involved in all components of the business. After spending a year focusing on the financial components, I am looking forward to studying the book ends of a global company. I am looking to be involved with the conceptual development of products design and creation. However, I want to see how the product can be fulfilled as apple does from all over the world. Currently my business is JIT based on products already in the domestic market. A very safe and controlled JIT model. Our value creation is based soley on design and creative printing methods we call multimedia. A simple supply chain in effect enables low barriers to entry and therefore has made it a commodity market. I want to be invovled with creating a company that creates the next iphone. So technologically advanced and able to reach the market we are able to build a loyal following.
the core of every successful country is production. I want to become a master at production before attempting to govern a nation onto prosperity and global impact.

I need a harvard MBA for 3 reasons: 1. For a short term that I can be accepted to McKinsey 2. I want to spend time at McKinsey before heading to a specific Company like VF Corp. 3. I want to learn from the best school - global supply chain and innovative product development in order to compete with the best in the world.

note.title: How do i buy companies for other companies?

notes.note: What are the skill sets in school i can study? What in mckinsey? Where can i do that for a company?

note.title: visionary and L&P talking to a weaker GMAT score.

notes.note: if i will go out on a limb and confess that who i am and am growing to be is a visionary. I am only as good as the people i surround myself with. my role also becomes necessary as i work with people who are smarter and better than myself, showing them how their skills are of great value to this team. I will never do well in an isolated, fast paced environment designed to trick me in the details, like the GMAT. If it were not in an academic setting, but in the real world, I would call on the men and women i have formed bonds with over time and we would have scored an 800. The visionary would call out the objective to my team. The philosopher in me would ask what are strageties and what's worked in the past. The Entrepreneure in me would build a micro-culture for the project of terms, roles, and buzz words so we could cut to the chase. The professions i am going into, while require analytical skills will be very team and case oriented. consulting at mcKinsey and CEO of VF Corp both are very team oriented and are working problems we are permitted to do research. When a problem in the professional world arrises that reminds me of the GMAT, I will lean on those skills, use a life line, and call my professors at Harvard for some help. everyone has an achillies heal and mine happens to be overly detail oriented situations that are complex and solo. however, look at my academic performance with my Masters in DU. I do what it takes...

I'm the guy who thinks of a new way to package, position, and sell soup. A new hybrid shopping experience of convenience and options in an building I call the convenience mall. Or a website designed to record the calls people make to financial institutions to turn their lack of responsibiltiy on them. I'm the guy who asks many questions like "what if..", or "let's say we needed to...", and "why do we...?" I'm also the guys who says "if we had to do that, what do you think it would take?" and "okay, when could we have that?" and "what would it take to have that in 6 months?"

my dad's dad was working on the railroad as a twenty-four year old when he read the book "think and grow rich". He didn't graduate from highschool, but went on to become the number 1 selling life insurance agent over 31,000 agents for metropolitan life. My dad chose to go to seminary instead of a liberal arts school. my mom is a graphic designer with her own business. her grand-dad was a famous canadian inventor of nautical tools but lost his fortune due to... I chose my undergrad to honor my dad. Liberty, more known for it's values and ethics than for it's academics was a truly solid foundation for an eighteen year old wanderer. My choice of advertising for a major was based on my comfort for creative visuals and communication. It wasn't until 3 years ago did i see the value in financial analysis. i figured strong sales would always compensate. my MS in Finance is to fill and complete that portion of academics before I receive my MBA.

i had made up my mind to get my MBA from a top 10 ranked school. When my GMAT didn't make the cut, I decided to go anyway and get a masters in Finance while preparing and retaking the GMAT. I studied for the GMAT, am taking my masters, running my own business and fathering a 6 month old child.

note.title: To become VC and church clothes

notes.note: I have to admit I was attached to the success of my first business to a fuault. The best thing that could have happened to me was for it to fail. I needed to see that I need to ask the tough questions. I also think about how hard I looked for a mentor when I was doing my business. I tried SCORE and my school but nothing happened. I feel like the voice to my younger self when I'm talking to these other entreprneurs. I am saying, if you want to succeed you need to look at it from this angle. Questions about distribution, market size, sustainability, scalability. I had tried to make my hobby a business by pushing it. I need to do more than push hard. I need to develop my quantitative skills. I knew I loved apparel, sales, and marketing, but I didn't know why I had failed. I took a job with another apparel company that I had met along the way and became their sales and marketing director for Nashville. In my entrepreneurial adventures. I feel I matured to a level where I realized that I love to see things succeed. I love the variety of small businesses. I love figureing out how to build something from nothing. I love figuring out how to find the market for the customers and building all the necessary policies and proceedures to make it work. I am doing that currently with my 2nd business. It is infnintately more sustainable. However, I don't want to just do it for the finanical rewards. I did it because my business partner wanted to do a business and I am honestly more excited about watching the person he's become in this process. He can attest to the fact that I'm setting him up for success. I want to continue that and I feel it's my best opportunity to contribute to america by helping passionate individuals achieve their dreams.

1. So I can consult 2. So I can VC 3. To polish my street smarts 4. It's the 'certificate' for investors and others to listen to me. 5. so i can help build true sustainable, scalable, large businesses that benefit society. My passion is passionate people. People are truly inspiring when they are inspired themselves. To assist those people in achieving their dreams in a way that can serve society would be a true honor and dream come true. Venture capital is a means to working with many people.

Like Harvard, I want to work at the best Consulting to work on the best cases. The best way to be noticed is to be where they look. supply chain - help bring products to market strategy - refine competitive strategies retail - know how to read a customer intersts exposure to vast knowledge - research, learning, databases, cases networking - the people are top notch broad experience base - working with multiple companies over 3 - 5 eyars strengthen my vc skills - this makes me a more prepared and experienced VC. able to bring entrepreneurs to a level of big business - I can teach with real case scenarios travel - i love to travel variety - I love new cases in new places

There is nothing that can charge me up more than being surrounded by passionate people. I have found the greatest number of thsoe are entrepreneurs trying to bring their ideas to life. I don't want to just do business, but to work and train, and mentor these guys.
2 careers. I am hoping to complete my VC work by the age of 45. I want to return to school for my JD and practice public laws for a few years pro bono.

note.title: My plans are bigger than myself

notes.note: every successful business, plan, or hobby that I have been involved in has only succeed when others participated. My ideas involve and require the active participation of others who are wired different than I. I have developed such a realization to the power of the Master Mind, I can't seem to create an idea that doesn't involve others. Ex- ABCD, AMB3R, Retail, Kiosks, Product Line

My place in MIT will be the one where I am in genine awe and respect for my invetor and engineer peers. I am the one who will say "WOW! I am amazed at that.. Now how can we turn that into a profitable business?" What do you need to get those resources? What's the next step?" Small bus w/o engineer single bus w/ engineer (sell it or my portion) Become a VC and work with multiple businesses with multiple engineers. web, retail, supply chain innovation, manf innovation.

One of the core needs of an entrepreneur is to continue meeting and networking. My role is to pull the pieces together and to find the missing ones. Be they finance, production, sales, marketing, distribution. This is a world where the competitive advantage is who do you know, and how can you think creatively to turn raw resources into a value added product or service. It is an understatement when I say that I have exhausted my network. An MBA from harvard accomplishes the folowing 4 things. First, it renews and elevates my network to exponential proportions. Being able to call on people and ask them who they know in china. 2nd, It is the familiar introduction I intend to utilize when cold calling on businesses and investors. My unknown business plan will not get me a meeting, my premier associations will. Once I am in the room, I will have to do the vision casting, which I am confident I can do. 3rd, an MBA calibrates my 10 years of street knowledge. While I have read over 200 books in the last decade, they have been at my whim and preference. While this makes for a nice breatdh, I feel that there are aspects that should be drilled deeper. 4th, I firmly believe that a nation's economy and production are key for it's success. I do not have a retirement plan, I have a political plan. After I complete my season of business, I intend to enter politics. I greatly admire Mitt Romney's approach. I want to spend the next 2 decades working in the business world and see what works and what policies will truly benefit working america. Only after I solid grasp there do I intend to begin a path toward political office of Governor and eventually President. I need a solid foundation and a reference point for those who come on board. A Prestigious School commands respect from those who are following.
I am excicted about passionate people succeeding. I want to know what gets a person jazzed and ask the questions to see what it would take to help them succeed.

The Name of the Event was "60 in 60", Sixty McDonald's Chicken McNuggets in 60 minutes, and these were not the all white meat type either. This was the first of many events that I would put on during my undergrad that led to being doned "All Business Dave". The 60 in 60 was one of 3 eating contests that I created, promoted, and planned for the day. The name stuck from all the micro-clubs I would start through collge including as mentioned the eating challenges, a music club, and my favorite the BYMC (Blow Your Mind Club) where the only requirement for membership was that you had to come up with a new idea each month that would "blow your mind." There other mentionables include a
1. CCP - working on a project for the community 2. DCSG - marketing consultant 3. Tim Russo - on financing a deal 4. Ouray Sportswear - consulted them on product development

An MBA from Harvard will accomplish 3 things for me: 1. It will formalize my education and 2. It will legitimize my education to align with the 2nd half of my longterm plans. The 2nd half is a period at mckinsey to prepare me for an executive level position for a fortune 500 company. 3. This sets me up in my 50 year plan. I consider small biz > Big Biz > Small Govt > Big Govt.
The first thing my boss said was "Dave, I know I stole your idea and did it behind your back."...

What the GMAT doesn't show. Determination Tenacity Initiative Vision Creativity Motivation drive Passion Teamwork Leadership Kindness Stewardship resourcefullness Compassion All that to say. While the GMAT is helpful to know if a student will grasp and maintain at the graduate level it could mislead you since I am already a grad student and I k ow what I want to do with my life according to my strengths as defined by various tests including - meyers Briggs, insights, career leader and others. I am a creative visionary with a philosophers head and an entrepreneurs heart, passionate about helping others achieve their dreams.

Let me use a well know example to explain my situation I am not the michael jordan who was cut by his high school team. I am the micheal Jordan that could be passed over by the portland trailblazers. I have already experienced the setbacks and used the to ignite an even stronger desire desire to succeed.

I can imagine there is a record number of analysts applying to these schools. While these are prestigious names, they are only one particular skill set, that of the core strength in the finance industry. I believe what I can bring to my relationship with these types is an entreprenuruail view of business and that there are other ways to create wealth in smaller ways that can grow large. ALso, their ability to create these high scores is that the GMAT is a very similar skill to what they do on an day in and day out basis. Where as I am thinking on a broader scale, I am not as trained to think at that level, and I do not intend to create that level of attention to detail.

one of the things that stood out and got me most excited about harvard is that what Dee said about the philosophy behind the case method. How the goal is that we are excited about the story regardless of what the task or industry is. I also want a thurough analysis of my skillsets and thoughts. With 500 cases, I really appreciated how the idea is that many areas of my lack of knowledge will be exposed. And that Harvard is the ideal environment to expose my weaknesses and forge by beign mentored and carried by my classmates. How Harvard actually looks on students who possess an above average insight to lead the group. I also absolutely love the idea of a required cirriculum. Dee made light of it as if it were something archaic, which is preceely why i love it. In spending the 8 years of my career in entreprensural ventures, I feel like i've created methods and thoughts out of necessaity. While it developed me into an avid and broad reader of 4 - 5 books a month on many subjects, I still often quested if i was heading in the right direction. I love the idea that I would be 'calibrated' by the best institution in the world. I would gladly take these courses even the ones I feel a strength in. That would give me the opportunity to teach and demonstrate my abilities. After the admissions process, the concept of trial and error is totally permittied and after spending over 100,000 investing in my own previous company, I would very much appreciate 'practice runs' in an evnrionment where I will encounter even broader ideas.

I also absolutely love the idea of a required cirriculum. Dee made light of it as if it were something archaic, which is preceely why i love it. In spending the 8 years of my career in entreprensural ventures, I feel like i've created methods and thoughts out of necessaity. While it developed me into an avid and broad reader of 4 - 5 books a month on many subjects, I still often quested if i was heading in the right direction. I love the idea that I would be 'calibrated' by the best institution in the world. I would gladly take these courses even the ones I feel a strength in. That would give me the opportunity to teach and demonstrate my abilities.

note.title: i'm a job maker... not taker

notes.note: I am a job maker, not a job taker. I would use the access of the degree to meet with other influential men to create companies in which men of this new day and age can thrive and support themselves.

I feel that one of the first things I do in a new environment is seek context. Try to get a sense of what's going on. I think that's why my first company succeeded and failed. Within the confines of a christian school, my tees were a big hit. It didn't dawn on me that the context may have changed once i moved outside of that. I want to go to school to be able to create and see the biggest context possible in any situation. An MBA is the ability to create a broad perspective and acknowledge multiple viewpoints. I admit that my context did not go as broad as it should have.
Anything developed is developed by a certain set of rules and decisions. The more one understands how the system is setup, the more success one would have in it. Harvard is the leading institution to

_VC, Why?_ _To help build businesses, Why?_ _Because I like inventing and producing things, Why?_ _My Skill is to ask the questions unto motivation_

In this limited essay I will spend it focusing on the first 20 years of my 50 year plan. These two decades involve the business world. My MBA and the 3-4 years thereafter at McKinsey are like DR and residency. After than I plan to spend the next 15 in either Private Equity building and developing businesses. This alings with my passions and will also influence how I intended to form and develop governmental policies when I run for govnor in 30 years.

THe parable of the tortoise and the hare has influenced my life immensely. As a 20 year old I made a conscious effort to build a broad and solid foundation so that I may not fail under the real pressure. An MBA is part of my mentality toward this foundation. I counted the risks and rewards when I started my first company. An ex - i was awarded $5,000 from a car insurance claim and choose to use that money for my business and drive a $500 sentra. I reasoned I will always be driving cars, so try this business while i have the opportunity. I wanted to come to school with questions prepared to ask and experiences to relate to the cirriculum being tought. I want it to be challenged and my philosophies expanded. I will use this MBA to complete what I call a residency with a consulting firm. after a formal business education of those two, I will work toward the Venture Capital sectors. The goals of enterprise is adding value. I believe this mentaility is the ideal for future govenerment leaders to think, how is this policy sustainable or adding value. Can it be measured effectively.

After my first company failed, I spent 3 years developing a model that was based on a three tier strategy. AMB3R was the first company working with this model of starting a company based on The second startup that I have been involved with. Responsible for leading a team of five members to establish the company. Initial startup began with one partner and we recruited all pieces.

After my first business failed I was anxious for another opportunity to run a company. AMB3R (pronounced "Amber") is the opportunity to test my new management theories and financial knowledge toward the goal of creating a profitable and sustainable startup. Fortunately, many of these theories have proven effective in regards to customer experience, systemization, and production management. Consider the viewpoint from the sales metric; We are on target to do $500,000 in revenues our first year and with the recent addition of two trained and well connected sales reps I am optimistic we will reach $2 Million in sales in 2009. I am excited about leading our team into additional in regards to production manuals, and financial streamlining to make our service even more customer service friendly.

While I was building Church Clothes as a hip tee shirt brand, I was often approached by bands who needed help with their tour merchandise. So I developed a part time revenue stream of design and production management for those clients. My "side business" started to encroach on the territory of Futureshirts so they offered me a position to work for them. During that time period I had just been married and Church Clothes was hitting some financial trouble so I took them up on the offer. I was responsible for finding and attracting new business as well managing the design and production portions of the task. I was promoted to the head of the marketing committee where I began a catalog and trade show presence. I also worked closely with IT and the graphic design department to build an exciting customer design experience.

During my undergrad I had to wear a tie to class so the last thing I wanted to do on Sunday was dress up for church. I made some tee shirts that had the words "church clothes" printed on them. People asked me where I got it, and when I told them I made it, they asked me to make them one. In total I sold around 12,000 shirts through one hundred retailers and two mall kiosks. I also had great fun producing a seven city music tour to promote the line near the retail stores who carried it. The tour consisted of a team of three rock bands, their management companies, a booking agency, the local promoters, and the local retailer to coordinate an exciting event. Other notable projects include producing and distributing 10,000 promotional DVDs. Marketing design and logistical details for trade-shows presence. Semi-annual Designing and development of seven to twelve new tees.

We require two recommendations which address the questions asked on our Recommendation Form. Additional recommendations may be submitted, but they should offer additional and valuable insight. Generally, work-related recommendations are more valuable than academic-related recommendations. We prefer that recommenders with web access and an email address submit their recommendations electronically. After you have contacted the recommenders about providing the recommendation, complete the form on the Recommender's page and check the "Please email this person a recommendation request" beneath each recommender you wish us to contact. They will be sent an email message with instructions and a web address to go to in order to complete your recommendation. To submit paper-based recommendations, you should download the Recommendation Form, print one copy for each recommender, and follow the directions provided on the form.
Recommendations should be provided from employers, supervisors, professors, or others who are able to comment on your professional and educational goals and potential.

Ideally, one of your letters of recommendation, or Career Progress Surveys, should be written by your current supervisor or manager. The second letter of recommendation also should be from someone who can objectively evaluate your professional performance as well as managerial and leadership potential, such as a former supervisor, previous employer, client, etc. If you are unable to ask a current supervisor or manager for a letter of recommendation, please include a brief statement regarding your choice in the Additional Information section of Part 2 of the application.

The Admissions Committee requires two recommendation letters, preferably from supervisors. An optional third recommendation letter may be submitted from a peer or other individual who knows you well and can best answer the questions posed on the recommendation form.

Recommendations provide an important opportunity for the Admissions Board to gain additional information about you. Consider the following guidelines when choosing recommenders: Your three recommenders should be people who are able to relate specific and relevant details about your abilities and performance: The Admissions Board may contact your recommenders to clarify or to gain additional information regarding your candidacy as well as to verify the content of the recommendations. All recommendations must be completed online. See the instructions listed in the “Recommendations” section of the online application for further information. It is your responsibility to ensure that all three recommendations are submitted online by the deadline date for the round in which you apply. However, you do not need to wait for your recommenders to submit their recommendations before submitting your application. Previous applicants have found it helpful to ask their recommenders to submit their forms the week prior to the applicant’s application deadline.

note.title: How can I assemble a business from scratch?

notes.note: What does it take to make a successful business, McGavier style? I want to know how to take whatever resources are in front of me and turn them into a working, profitable, viable business. What components am I missing? _1/15/08_ I wrote in my "journal":https://123.writeboard.com/8b1e3f122cefaef6d that as a scientist, I want to create something of enduring value. I'm not sure if it's just that this journey requires years and trial and error. I see these other young businesses just killing it. But is that giving me the wrong perspective. Lord show me how you would have me to live and work. _3/12_ I have been learning about leases and never really knew how they could help me get my business off the ground. I don't need a huge capital investment, but cashflow to be able to sustain that monthly payment. A single bank loan would help bring that runway... _4/30_ While we haven't actually fully completed the sales cycle to receive payment for services, it appears that AMB3R has been established fairly smoothly. We are still waiting to setup our accounts with banks and credit cards, but it seems to be going smooth so far. We already have $50,000 in sales in only 2 weeks of being setup! _7/5_ I had a 'white out' experience that I feel may have cleared this drive and desire. I feel that this may have come from my wisdom of how life should be done. I think more so I want to engage in people in a work environment. I want them to see Christ.

I'm trying my hand at mySQL, Ruby on rails, etc. I would just ask for wisdom to know how to use these programs and how they can contribute to my tool belt of skills. I ask for an increased capacity and comprehension. Would You show me what to learn, how to learn it, and what to do about it. _Aril 13_ I'm only 3 months into this process and I would say that I've covered a lot of ground. This process is a unique one because, while I have seen some small progress, it seems to require the entire process to really work effectively. I know that I'm going to know only what God wants me to. I'm praying He leads me to be able to setup a site without any trouble...

God knows the situation better than I do. And He can give peace today b/c He created and lives in TODAY. God will Give me what I ask for Service to others is acceclerating (and blessing) my own responsiblities. God is establishing me and my seed, and building up my throne to all generations

We are here but there is still much to do. Lord would you have Mercy and favor on us. You Brought us this far. May I become established in my work, homelife, mental state, deepening with Danae. May I become a servant and would you take these impurities that have come to the surface and nail them to Your tree. _4/28_ Mom came for 3 days and turned our apartment into a home. It is amazing the job she did to clean, organize, and contribute to our settling. Our place is so cozy and relaxing, giving Us some great breathing and thinking room. I am so grateful.

note.title: Walking in Christ. In peace and in faith

notes.note: Life is such a strange place where the circumstances can be the same, but the result or purpose does different things. I feel like I'm watching my vocation and finances run on shaky, unreliable methods. I am asking for 2 things 1. Lord lead us out of this place! Put us on a rock higher than we could climb. Be the fuel we need to establish us. 2. May I have true peace and joy in this journey while we are in this season. That I may be fully attentive and surrendering that Christ may live and pour into those around me. Danae, son, family, friends, and co-workers.
That Christ would be my focus and life in the upcoming 3 - 4 months with: * Baby due July * Looking to start a company to make some cash * Starting school August
Picking the proper program. Staying on course with entrance requirements. Balancing - Work, Home, School.
Lord, I need You to establish our home, marriage, and work. New baby Romantic Husband Work so to get out of debt Unless You do so, we are undone.

note.title: Go before me today and prepare the way

notes.note: God, You hold all things together. This day requires Your presence in the 'good' and the 'bad' both of which, while I am privileged to experience, I can not judge which is which. May I remain in You and walk in Your Life. I would ask for Your favor on AMB3R's finances, sales, establishment, people help, suppliers, manufacturing, my relationship with Jeremy, Artists, and clients. I would pray that in Your mercy, You would redeem this Passion client. Nevertheless my hope is in You. Thank You for the chance to do Switchfoot, and Johnny Cupcakes.

It sounds funny. But I've been really influenced by this reality that people's first impression of you is key to effectiveness. We don't realize how prone we are to how people put themselves together. I'm praying for a new wardrobe. I haven't really ever thought of my dress this way and I want to start DU properly. I would love to basically throw out all my old clothes and start over with a new 2 weeks worth of clothing.
Lord, if this is the way that You have... Would you bring confirmation. The idea of a 650 + GMAT score is daunting and the idea of doing a 5 term MSF in 4 with honors. Your life and will endures...

Scheduling - _Classes, trips, etc._ Our finances - _Loans and living expenses_ Managing AMB3R - _Handling the work load and adding more sales_ Grasping my classes - _I NEED ALL A's!_ Preparing for the GMAT - _Strategies, memorization, grasping_ Searching and finding the right school - _which top?_ Time management - _Balancing all these activities_ Serving Danae - _Loving her and helping her_ Abiding - _Abiding in Christ_

I am going to retake this test in about 6-7 weeks. It is daunting because of the way the test is formatted. It's unreal how much weight is placed on this test! _I surrender my life to You Lord and ask You for Your peace, comprehension, insight, and discernment to lead me over this 3 part test of verbal, writing, and analytical. I would ask You to bless me with a high score and insight into an MBA program You would call me to._

note.title: Business School Selection and Application process

notes.note: Lord, You are our Father and Guide. You are leading us and worship and thank You for doing so. I believe life is a journey but I don't know how it's lived. My prayer is that You lead and establish us in Your way. Please lead me to the right school. THe right program. The right teaching methods and work loads. The right network. Please develop and refine these essays content, priority, and purpose. I submit this challenge to You and hold You responsible for this Life; For it is Yours in me. _Bless Danae and Oscar. We are trusting you for food and clothing._

Oh Lord, I call upon Thy Mercy. I have 15 days until I take this test and I still feel under prepared. I need Your wisdom, direction, clarity, and insight to the test, it's content, and strategies. I am asking for You to lead me to the place that I may score a 700 or somewhere near there. However, I do acknowledge that You are the one with the plan. I am asking that You teach me to labor, and then bless the fruits of the labor.

I am meeting with the Ouray guys today and I confess I don't know what will come of it or what I should be doing with them. _Lord, I ask that you lead me in the ways in which we should go. Be my wisdom and words as I speak and listen._

We thought we had our house in Nashville sold until last month when the Lease/purchase people left without notice. There are some plumbing issues with pipes freezing and we have to repaint before it can be rented out again. Thankfully we paid January but it appears we'll have to pay February's mortgage as well. We need to get rid of that house. Long distance management is too much. _Lord, have mercy on us and that house. We ask that You help us sell it and if it be Your will, that we can make some money to repay for these months._

The put allows its buyer the right but not the obligation to *sell* a commodity or financial instrument (the underlying instrument) to the writer (seller) of the option at a certain time for a certain price (the strike price). The writer (seller) has the *obligation to purchase* the underlying asset at that strike price, *if the buyer exercises the option.* _The put *buyer* either believes it's likely the price of the underlying asset will fall by the exercise date, or hopes to protect a long position in the asset. The advantage of buying a put over short selling the asset is that the risk is limited to the premium._ _The put *writer* does not believe the price of the underlying security is likely to fall. The writer sells the put to collect the premium._
"Wiki":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Put_option

A call option is a financial contract between two parties, the buyer and the seller of this type of option. The buyer of the option has the right, but not the obligation to buy an agreed quantity of a particular commodity or financial instrument (the underlying instrument) from the seller of the option at a certain time (the expiration date) for a certain price (the strike price). The seller (or "writer") is obligated to sell the commodity or financial instrument should the buyer so decide. The buyer pays a fee (called a premium) for this right. The buyer of a call option wants the price of the underlying instrument to *rise in the future*; the seller either expects that it will not, or is willing to give up some of the upside (profit) from a price rise in return for the premium (paid immediately) and retaining the opportunity to make a gain up to the strike price (see below for examples). *Call options are most profitable for the buyer* when the underlying instrument is *moving up*, making the price of the underlying instrument closer to the strike price. When the price of the underlying instrument surpasses the strike price, the option is said to be "in the money".
"wiki":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_option

"Investment Biker":http://www.amazon.com/Investment-Biker-Around-World-Rogers/dp/1558505296 | "Adventure Capitalist":http://www.amazon.com/Adventure-Capitalist-Ultimate-Road-Trip/dp/0812967267/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1235099410&sr=1-6

What works in the US? What works overseas? *Momentum* "Winners" - _stocks that have out performed over the past year_ Winning stocks tend out perform for about a year after they've been classified as winners. "Losers" - _stocks that have underperformed over the past year._ Same with losers. This is public information _Momentum occurs in US and other major markets_ *Size* In US small companies have stocks that out perform over longer periods of time. Small companies tend to be riskier. Trend occurs in other markets as well, Europe especially. *Value Vs. Growth* Value stocks outperform growth stocks in the US Value can be meared by" P/E - Low number is value Book-to-market ratio - high number is value

image.description: *Buying a put option* - This is a graphical interpretation of the payoffs and profits generated by a put option as seen by the buyer of the option. A lower stock price means a higher profit. Eventually, the price of the underlying security will be low enough to fully compensate for the price of the option.

*Writing a put option* - This is a graphical interpretation of the payoffs and profits generated by a put option as seen by the writer of the option. Profit is maximized when the price of the underlying security exceeds the strike price, because the option expires worthless and the writer keeps the premium.

*Buying a call option* - This is a graphical interpretation of the payoffs and profits generated by a call option from the buyer 's perspective. The higher the stock price the higher the profit. Eventually, the price of the underlying security would become high enough to fully compensate for the price of the option.

*Writing a call option* - This is a graphical interpretation of the payoffs and profits generated by a call option from the writer 's perspective of the option. Profit is maximized when the strike price exceeds the price of the underlying security, because the option expires worthless and the writer keeps the premium.

notes.note: Hi Everyone. I hope the Winter term is off to a great start for you! I thought the CCP Fair was a great end to Fall quarter and now we need to plan for the completion of BUS 4615. There are three requirements to complete BUS 4615 during the next eight weeks(see below and attached document). Please contact me at shartley@du.edu to set up a meeting! 1. To begin phase two of Bus 4615 and your CCP projects please submit no more than a 100 word abstract on blackboard which will help with tracking and project reviews. If your CCP team has identified a specific organization as the focus of your project please include that information in the abstract. In addition, please indicate the issue area i.e., education, homelessness. CCP Abstracts should be submitted to blackboard in Compass-CCP FA08SP09. Due date 10pm, February 2, 2009 Format requirements: Title including team name and section number 100 word abstract/CCP project description Community Partner, if relevant. 2. Final Community Capital Report (approximately 3,000 words), picking up where the team was at the end of autumn quarter and describing the remainder of the project phases. This paper will synthesize course material into the team’s identification and evaluation of alternative solutions for the identified community capital gap, and will use course material to justify the conceptual design for the solution or the “no-go” decision. The paper must demonstrate comprehensive understanding of the academic material presented in the Essence course, and how that material is used in a real business enterprise (profit or nonprofit). Grading for the content of paper is based on Bloom’s Taxonomy. The quality of the writing for each paper will be evaluated under the “3 strike” rule: 3 writing errors will result in a deduction of 5% from your percentage score for the paper. Writing errors include errors in punctuation, spelling, grammar, word choice (e.g., using the incorrect homonym), and typographical errors. Due date 10 pm, March 20, 2009 3. Two Oxford style meetings with Steve Hartley. Please prepare for these meetings as you did with the Oxford Engagements by getting together as a team prior to meeting with faculty to discuss the CCP project. I will be asking you to apply the readings from last quarter to the project in specific detail. By the end of the quarter, the team should be able to make a well-informed recommendation on whether to move forward with the project (go/no go). Either choice is fine, as long as the decision is substantiated through primary research data points gained through the community exploration phase in the Fall quarter, and synthesis with the Essence readings. During our two Oxford meetings this quarter, I will be asking you to discuss the decision criteria for making the go/no go choice. If the decision is to move forward, a part of the final paper should address the steps to make the project sustainable over future quarters. (This could involve passing your project on to another team in the spring or fall, or putting in place a plan for some other partner to carry on your Community Capital Project.) Due date for first meeting is by February 13, 2009, and the second meeting is by March 9, 2009. You may build the documentation of your CCP in the wiki tool located in your Blackboard container for BUS 4615. You have a deliverable for each quarter of the project, but you are encouraged to think of developing the deliverable for each phase as part of a whole, showing the work done at each step, but also showing the interconnectedness of the phases. I'll look forward to hearing from you!

"Silent Voice" is a tool for classrooms to assist in bridging the gap of communication between students and their teacher. Middle school and high school is a difficult time for students and they may be introverted or insecure, thereby making it uncomfortable to raise their hand to ask questions for clarification on difficult topics. The Silent Voice will anonymously tally a vote if students need more clarification about the topic based on a hanging scoreboard showing a %. The teacher will know if they can move on or need to spend some more time in discussion.
The paper must demonstrate comprehensive understanding of the academic material presented in the Essence course, and how that material is used in a real business enterprise (profit or nonprofit)

Email me your abstract and a short status report. The status report should include (a) selection of alternatives (if applicable), (b) project outcomes and metrics for the outcomes, and (c) a timetable for your remaining activities before you submit your final report. Please copy your entire team. I'll follow up on email.

Accounts receivable consists of tenant improvement receivables, credit card receivables, and miscellaneous receivables. The allowance for doubtful accounts is the Company’s best estimate of the amount of probable credit losses in the Company’s existing accounts receivable based on a specific review of account balances. Account balances are charged off against the allowance after all means of collection have been exhausted and the potential for recoverability is considered remote.

AMB3R's experienced Fashion & Design teams make it easy to make t-shirts your customers want to wear! |Step 1| Set the parameters Set your Project Parameters based on your in hand date, qty, project goals, and budget. You can submit art, or you can tell us what you want, or we can offer suggestions based on what you're project is all about. [ See All Design Kits ] |Step 3| Develop a Fashion Kit with AMB3R's Fashion & Style team Computers don't invent fashions, humans with funny hair styles do. Twitter has "four types of API's":https://dev.twitter.com/start . Ordered from lean, to most robust features. *1. Twitter for Websites* Basic like "Follow", "Tweet to" Button, etc. *2. Search API* Ability to find trends from users, words, trends, etc. This allows you to pull, but not manipulate data. *3. REST API* Access core features including timeline and status. Additionally, you can create, reply, and more from your app, using REST API *4. Streaming API* Real-time information, suited for analytic research and data mining type of apps. Allows for large quantitates of data.

From page "Using the Twitter Search API":https://dev.twitter.com/docs/using-search http://search.twitter.com/search.json?q=cahack&include_entities=true&rpp=2&page=4 *Breakdown* .json - format ?q - beginning of query cahack - search term & - chains on additional filters include_entities - twitter method, (Specifically more info about the tweet) =true - the condition passed to the method (include_entities) ... rinse and repeat.

1. made a controller w/ index & show view 2. made an form_tag 3. built actions for show, 4. method for the query using Rahgu's .Json parse code. 5. got our url from search.twitter, and reformatted it for .json (using "constructing a query":https://dev.twitter.com/docs/using-search) 6. out put to the view (through an array & block)

Using the right technology, this project should take you no more than a day to complete. Write a web application that implements the following user stories: User can log in User can log out When the user is logged in… they can add a book to their favorites. Information about the book should include the title and the author. they can view a list of their favorite books. they can delete a book from their favorites. they can browse books that other users have added. when viewing a book that other users have added, they can add it to their own list of favorites. Don’t worry as much about the visual look and feel of the application, focus more on whether it is correct and flows easily, i.e.accomplishes the above user stories in a way that is most useful to the book loving end user. Depending on your specific skills, we suggest using a framework such as Rails (Ruby), Flex, .Net, Grails (Java/J2EE) or MonoRail (.NET). Most are freely available and have extensive tutorials online. Finally, make sure to write unit and integration tests that do a good job of covering the application. Test Driven Development is central to everything we do, so we’ll be very interested in seeing these tests.

*Slide Tips-* * Decide who and how many are presenting * Write out your deck as a story first * Build slides off of what you've written * Make your slides 1080p so they scale to the full projection (need help? ask me!) * Fewer words the better, fewer slides the better * Use big BIG fonts * If your slide is an image, make it the full slide with no heading * Use stark contrast so nothing gets washed out * Screencast your applications using Quicktime, Camtasia, Screenflow. Edit them using iMovie. *Things to mention-* * Introduce your team, who's on it, from what class * Briefly tell me about the future of your application. Not necessarily features, but if you intend to continue building it, if/when it's going live to the public, if it's just a fun side project, etc. * What's your 'ask'? For the audience to sign up, for advice, beta testers? *On Stage Tips-* * Project into the Mic. Hold it really close to your mouth and speak loudly into it. * Don't ask the audience if they can hear you, the staff will let you know * Add tiny pauses to your speaking repertoire to let the audience digest the information *Don't do-* * Don't be nervous. We're all here to support you. Just go up there and show us what your team has built, everything else will fall into place. * Don't start by asking the audience a question. Find a hook through a story or an example. _(Personal pet peeve of mine, feel free to disagree)_ * Don't point at a screen or monitor, we can't see what you're pointing at * Try not to look behind you at the slides, face your audience, make eye contact *Remember to-* * Practice, practice, practice. Then practice some more. *Examples-* * TechCrunch Disrupt has startups on stage for 5 minutes demonstrating their application. See what inspires you. Here's the team that won the previous * Disrupt: http://techcrunch.com/2012/05/21/uber-conference/
http://downloads.gosquared.com/help_sheets/10/CSS3%20Help%20Sheet%20outlined.pdf CSS3 Cheat Sheet - http://www.veign.com/downloads/guides/qrg0008.pdf
* Design for hackers - Jeremy Keith * Designing the Web Standards - Jeffrey Zeldman

As you prep for Demo Day, I thought it would be helpful to watch some great 3-minute presentations from TED conferences over the years. Now don't worry about being as good as these presentations, just focus on how they were able to fit a great presentation in 3-5 minutes. Richard St. John - 8 secrets of success I like this video because he finds a way to pack a lot of content into a small window. I also like the first and last secret to success. Have you heard these before? ;) http://www.ted.com/talks/richard_st_john_s_8_secrets_of_success.html Derek Sivers - How to start a movement Great use of a hilarious video to demonstrate the keys to starting a movement. Short, funny, and full of impact. http://www.ted.com/talks/derek_sivers_how_to_start_a_movement.html Ric Elias - 3 things I learned while my plane crashed Now this one is over 3 minutes, but this is one of the best examples of story-telling to communicate the key points of conversation, so I have to throw it in! No you don't have to have stories as scary as this one, but think about how to craft your experience into a compelling story when building your presentation. http://www.ted.com/talks/ric_elias.html

page.title: Web Dev Spring 2012 (My copy)
page.notes:
*Monday*: A lot of orientation, plus a little coding! We got our first look at the Input-Processing-Output pattern, learned a few Terminal commands, and began writing some HTML. *Tuesday*: A lot of orientation, plus a little coding! We got our first look at the Input-Processing-Output pattern, learned a few Terminal commands, and got our first look at HTML. We then added some CSS (both inline and external). Finally, we got a chance to run the @ruby@ interpreter on our program of @puts@ statements to display a list of landmarks. *Wednesday*: We added some CSS to our HTML list of landmarks, then learned how to use the @link@ tag to reference an external stylesheet instead. We made our HTML into a valid HTML document (@html@, @head@, and @body@ tags) and then rewrote the program in Ruby. We covered the @puts@ statement, the @ruby@ and @irb@ commands, and began to use variables to hold data. Finally, we removed a lot of duplication in our code by learning how to define our own methods with the @def@..@end@ pair. *Thursday*: We covered… a ton: local variables, block variables, double-quote strings vs. single-quote strings, symbols, blocks, and loops. *Friday*: We continued thinking about how to automate and remove the repetition in our code from Wednesday. We learned about the @times@ method, and how we can use it to repeat a *block of code* a given number of times. We then got an introduction to how to manage *lists of things* using either arrays or hashes. We saw how to iterate through a list by using the @times@ method, the @each_with_index@ method, and at long last the easy-to-use @each@ method. Knowing how to use the @each@ method is an essential skill to iterating over (or "looping over") an array of data. We ended with a quick look at how to use symbols instead of strings for our hash keys.
<note id="6870175" title=""Learn to Program [pdf/book/both]":http://pragprog.com/book/ltp2/learn-to-program or "Learn to Program [book, cheap]":"http://www.amazon.com/Program-Second-Edition-Facets-Series/dp/1934356360/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1334086524&sr=8-1" created_at="2012-04-10 19:35:36"/>
<note id="6870178" title=""Raghu's Page with Challenges/Exercises":https://codeacademy.backpackit.com/pages/2679498-raghu-s-home-page" created_at="2012-04-13 01:54:08"/>
*Monday*: A quick review of hashes and arrays, and also saw how to use the @new@ method to create new hashes, arrays, and strings. We also learned the @push@ and "shovel" operators to append data to strings and arrays. We created our own @Person@ class and learned about the difference between the class "blueprint" and the individual instances. We then learned about instance variables that are accessible throughout an entire class. Finally we created a bank account class with attributes and methods. *Tuesday* We covered *everything from Monday (above)*, plus we built a small shopping cart application in Ruby, and also got a glimpse of how to create HTML files using Ruby code by using the @File@ class. "Go to Raghu's page for complete code and exercises":https://codeacademy.backpackit.com/pages/2679498-raghu-s-home-page *Wednesday* We used the @mate .@ command from Terminal to open up an entire folder inside of Textmate, and also learned a bit about passing options to the @ls@ command. We then grew some orange trees and got a first look at methods that have question marks, methods that have exclamation points, and the @if@ statement in Ruby. Then we dove into a long lab where we created two classes of our own to keep track of items in a shopping cart. "Go to Raghu's page for complete code and exercises":https://codeacademy.backpackit.com/pages/2679498-raghu-s-home-page *Thursday*: We got started with Rails! We created a new app called @FirstApp@ and got our first look at how controllers, actions, and views connect to each other. We also used ERb to embed Ruby logic right into our HTML templates. *Friday*: Hello Rails! We created a new app and used the 4-Step "RCAV" recipe to generate web pages for any URL we wanted. We used ERb to embed Ruby logic right into our HTML templates.
# Create some Ruby hashes that contain data for all of the cars you can see on your block. # Create an array of names of colors as symbols. Generate a list of colors, displayed in uppercase. # Create a class that can be used to represent a team. Create instances for four teams. A team consists of a name and a mascot name. # Write a Ruby program to print the lyrics to _"99 Bottles of Beer"_
1. Create a Rails application that displays a list of your favorite movies. 2. Create a Rails application that redirects users to other sites based on the last part of the URL, like this: * ==http://localhost:3000/microsoft== should redirect users to ==http://www.microsoft.com== * ==http://localhost:3000/google== should redirect users to ==http://www.google..com== * ==http://localhost:3000/twitter== should redirect users to ==http://www.twitter..com== 3. Create a Rails application that lets users submit restaurant recommendations.
*Monday*: Models! After reviewing some fundamentals of routes and actions, we created "model" classes to represent our real-world objects. We used the model generator to create database-backed models, and took a look at migrations and the rails console. *Tuesday*: Quick review of RVAC, and then we started creating models: simple Ruby classes that are intended to model our application's problem domain. We used the model generator to create database-backed models, and took a look at migrations and the rails console. We used the @.all@ and @.find_by_id@ methods to load data from the database into instance variables in our controller actions, to allow our views to be data-driven instead of containing hardcoded HTML. *Wednesday*: We started a new Rails app, and generated a Flavor model. We then created a page to list all the flavors in our database, and created a form that lets us create new flavors without having to use the Rails console. We saw how the @params@ hash gives us access to data submitted by a form. *Thursday and Friday*: We continued our app by routing 7 complete actions: index, show, new, create, edit, update, and destroy. We can now CRUD our data entirely within our web app!
*Monday*: We reviewed how to build all 7 actions for a resource from scratch again: index, show, new, create, edit, update, destroy. *Tuesday*: We reviewed how to build all 7 actions for a resource from scratch again: index, show, new, create, edit, update, destroy. We then started to apply the DRY and Clear Intention principles by using named routes, @form_for@ for model-backed forms, and "partials" for eliminating duplicate code in our views. *Wednesday*: We then started to apply the DRY and Clear Intention principles by using named routes and @form_for@ for model-backed forms. We finished by using the @flash@ hash to display brief notification messages to our users. *Thursday*: Model validations, error messages, flash messages, and how to rollback migrations. *Friday*: Model validations, error messages, Git, GitHub, and Heroku.
* Seeds * Multiple Representations * Named Routes * Model Validations * Forms * Partials * Migrations * Source Control with Git * Deployment to Heroku
* Git usage * "Mass assignment" for model attributes * HTTP client: cURL * Configuration: understanding the application.rb file * Gemfile 101 * Gems: thin and quiet_assets * Model Associations: one-to-many associations * Migrations 201 * User Stories * The @#order@ method * Model calculation methods * Creating view helpers
*Monday* Git, mass assignment, Curl, Gems, and scaffold. *Tuesday* Git, mass assignment, Curl, Gems, scaffold, and starting to use @belongs_to@ on a one-to-many relationship. *Wednesday* We hand-wrote our own implementations of @belongs_to@ and @has_many@ as we explored how to build one-to-many associations. We created a column in our @items@ table (for the @Item@ model) so that we can track the category ID for each item. *Thursday and Friday* We learned about @has_many@ and the "proxy" object that we can use to refine our use of the database. We also looked at the @order@ method to sort data, in ascending or descending order. We then build the FriendBC app, learning about how to use public APIs to get JSON data, parse it into a hash, and mash it up into our own web app!
* User Stories * Cookies * Sessions * Modeling: 1-to-n and n-to-n associations * User accounts: signup/sign in/sign out * Filters * View helpers
* Authentication vs. Authorization * Search functionality * Hidden Form Fields * Pagination * User Accounts * Sign Up * Sign In * Sign Out * Model Callbacks * Mailers * Environment Variables * Advanced ActiveRecord

notes.note: Thanks for visiting! Here are some of the demos that the design class would love to see. If you're familiar with any of the tools and techniques below and would be available to visit the class (Tues/Thursday 1-6pm) - please email Carolyn at cchandler@manifestdigital.com.

note.title: From PSD to HTML: Building a Set of Website Designs Step by Step

notes.note: Today I’m going to take you through my entire process of getting from Photoshop to completed HTML. We’re going to build out a set of 4 PSD mockups of a website that eventually will become a WordPress theme. It’s a massive tutorial, so if you’re going to follow through to the end, make sure you have a few hours to spare! DO THIS - http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/site-builds/from-psd-to-html-building-a-set-of-website-designs-step-by-step/

note.title: Responsive Web Design: A Visual Guide

notes.note: These days, “one size fits all” is quickly becoming a dated concept. Luckily, with CSS media queries, we can now easily build responsive web designs that accomodate everything from your mobile phone, up to your massive desktop! http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/html-css-techniques/responsive-web-design-a-visual-guide/

note.title: Mastering CSS, Part 1: Styling Design Elements

notes.note: Below are fresh tips and techniques for creating and styling design elements with CSS. They’re a good place to start if you’re new to CSS but are valuable even if you’re a veteran designer. Not all the techniques are strictly CSS; some include integration with JavaScript or XHTML to extend the functionality of your site. http://coding.smashingmagazine.com/2009/08/03/mastering-css-styling-design-elements/

note.title: CSS: Noob to Ninja – The Complete Video Series

notes.note: This exclusive premium video series will take you from a state of absolute CSS “noobness,” all the way up to ninja-status, capable of taking advantage of the latest CSS3 techniques. The series begins with the basics: the syntax, properties, etc. However, each new video expands upon the previous, as you work your way up and improve your skills. In this final week, you’ll complete the series, as you gain access to Parts 8-12: five new episodes. I have this… if you want it, you should email me :)

The goal here is a background image on a website that covers the entire browser window at all times. Let's put some specifics on it: Fills entire page with image, no white space Scales image as needed Retains image proportions (aspect ratio) Image is centered on page Does not cause scrollbars As cross-browser compatible as possible Isn't some fancy shenanigans like Flash http://css-tricks.com/perfect-full-page-background-image/

What once required background images and icons can now be created with plain-old CSS. Because modern browsers have access to things like box shadow, gradients, rounded corners, text-shadows, and font-face, we can finally take advantage of this and remove any need for images, when creating visual elements, such as buttons! I’ll show you how in today’s video tutorial. http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/html-css-techniques/build-kick-ass-practical-css3-buttons/

note.title: How to Create a Slick and Clean Button in Photoshop

notes.note: This Photoshop tutorial shows you how to create a simple and clean "Web 2.0 style" button sprite with a rollover state. You’ll also learn how to set up the sprite using some basic CSS techniques (CSS background sprite and CSS text image replacement). http://sixrevisions.com/tutorials/photoshop-tutorials/how-to-create-a-slick-and-clean-button-in-photoshop/

note.title: Create an Animated .GIF in Photoshop CS5

You can find special programs online to do this, but with some of the new features of Adobe Photoshop CS5, it’s quite fast and simple. http://www.briandalessandro.com/blog/create-an-animated-gif-in-photoshop-cs5/

Creating an image only for the purpose of displaying a gradient is inflexible, and is quickly becoming a bad practice. Textmate Basics Tutorial – http://projects.serenity.de/textmate/tutorials/basics/ Learning TextMate – http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/tools-and-tips/essential-textmate-shortcuts-tips-and-techniques/

Top 15 TextMate Shortcuts – http://benrasmusen.com/work/top-15-textmate-shortcuts/ Great wallpaper for your laptop/personal computer – http://scottboms.com/2007/01/textmateshortcutsdesktop/ These get a little advanced, but will become more helpful as you go through your Rails journey – http://ionrails.com/2009/09/23/textmate-shortcuts-cheatsheet/

ctrl - shift - d :: _duplicates the current line of code_ cmd - r :: _when in 'Ruby' will run the function in pop up window_ cmd - t :: _'Go to file' let's you search for a file instead of navigating to it manually_ ctrl - shift - . :: _imbed <%= %> ruby code into HTML; release and type . again to remove =_ ctrl - shift - , (comma) :: _creates html tag_ esc :: _autocomplete for your variable, method, etc._ command - / :: _convert snippet into comment_ def + tab :: _autocomplete method_ option - cmd - . :: _Close most recently opened html tag_ cmd - shift - f :: Find/replace all instances in textmate files highlight text and cmd - / :: Comment selected lines ctrl - shift - j :: join next line with the current line shift - crtl - t :: in conjunction with _TODO_, _FIXME_, _CHANGED_, shows index of all todo/fixme/changed comments opt - cmd - . :: textmate will infer the proper end tag cmd - shift - +/- :: Increase/decrease font size ctrl - cmd - w :: close all tabs open in textmate cmd - [ or ] :: indent highlighted code left or right ctrl - shift - h :: Highlight a block of code, Textmate will render it a partial cmd + opt + ctrl + d :: show/hide drawer _keep adding shortcuts to this note to help us aggregate them all._

* cmd - k :: clear terminal * irb :: ruby in terminal * object.methods :: lists an array of all available methods * mate . :: opens each text in current directory * ↑ :: last typed terminal command * sudo :: forces permission for task * ctrl - c :: force quit running command, or exit server * autocomplete - start typing a file name, or letter and "tab" to autocomplete file * navigate to folder with spaces in title :: use \ in between or autocomplete
* require 'classes' :: enables classes * exit :: quit * load 'filename.rb' :: loads ruby textmate file, inclusive of classes _feel free to keep adding to this note_

If you would like to expand the functionality of TextMate on your personal computers, check out PeepOpen - http://peepcode.com/products/peepopen PeepOpen is a file navigation application that works with TextMate to help search on both paths and filenames, and easily open the file in your text editor with a single key press.

notes.note: Hey I'm Dave, I have two boys and do what I can to help prepare them for life. After we established the ability to count to 10, I began to wonder if they knew what the difference was between the numbers. My next task in teaching them way the idea of 'value' and 'movement' So, I started doing different exercises. I started by; 1. Teaching the sentence that 'math is how numbers play together' 2. Math playground 3. which cat is bigger, the 1 year old or the 5 year old cat? 4. then, I started saying 'plus goes up' and 'minus goes down' One day it kind of clicked that I could turn this into a board game. Since I'm a designer & developer, I decided to make a game and website. Turns out Oscar loves CatMathDo and we play it more often than connect four, go fish, or other toddler games. I don't know what else to do with the game right now, so I'm just giving the PDF away for free. Take it to kinkos. Also, you can buy bingo chips from this supplier; I'd love to know what your experience is playing with CatMathDo. It would mean a lot if you post something on my Facebook page, or mention me in a tweet :-) Thanks! Dave

10/14/13 Nearly a year since my last post. Wow, what a journey. Highlights are; * Working at livingsocial for 10 months now. Wow, I can't believe I have an extended work experience! Thank You LORD for sustaining and leading us. * Learning Angular 11/16/13 part 2 Profile Today I added a profile resource to DAT. Per architecture learned from 3R. Helpers Application Controller Had issues with tags that i moved into application controller. I was testing on curren_user. First time i used '!!' to convert a nil to true/false!. Observer Built a Createprofileobserver which was pretty sweet! View github 11/16/13
Been a great week. I'm spending time learning the supporting pieces and filling in the holes. middleman Finally took a look at the MM app and how easy it is to get a project started. It was a little tough at first to get all the pieces, config and hosting. Not 100% yet on hosting, but I know that will work out just fine! I see using that framework for static sites. raingular Finally got the angular to show on my rails app! WooHoo! next stop, ScreenPrintly! started afterburners.mx Maybe I'll do that as another side project. interviewed With tendril and davinci coders. Not sure when and how my career path is going, but I'm not responsible. Asset Pipeline Two main issues is that it can provide caching and reduces requests to one file. 11/11
Rails Added background job. Added a service object module - I dig it! Added redis, then realized that a worker is expensive on heroku so I'm going to come back to that later Angular Don't forget to use '$scope' as part of variable names when in a controller Console log my way into a working controller before getting into a view. Job Got my 30 day notice. This is the stage of learning little by little. Thank You, Lord. You are a provider and protector. 11/7
Raingular Started a toy app to learn rails and angular. So far, it's slowing coming together. I'm overall encouraged by how it's developing. I started a twitter handle to document progress for my own sake. I hit a few deploy issues with Rails 4 on heroku. So, It was cool to over come those - specifically with assets and how they are now compiled with a 12factor gem. Current issues I still can't get angular to load on heroku, but fortunately that's a minor, single problem I expect to have solved next week. Thank you, Lord for teaching me the way You do. 11/7/13
Completed the Angular-Rails pdf Thoughts on it; 1. got lost in some of the magical javascript. 2. worked, but didn't get it to work completely. 3. learned the basic structure of how the two work together. 4. gave me things to know what to look for as I move forward, like Next steps build a dummy raingular app. finish angular book read github angular.js wiki 11/5/13
Trying to understand all the components of Rails & Angular and how a request is made. 11/5/13
Rails & Angular Checklist of things to build (as I currently understand them) Rails Model Controller (To be API) [File].json.builder (To provide content to view) Angular App.js (Informs which view and controller to use based on route) Service (To grab json content) Controller (Business logic) Views applicationlayout.html (rails view wrapper) [rubyview].html (rails specific action page - can be used to house individual ng-apps with extra content, or disregarded and used with simply ng-view) [ng_view].html (angular page - where all the content is loaded) 11/5/13
Things I feel I know so far That I like to learn I can teach beginners I can build small, CRUD apps I am good with people I can perform once I have my bearings 11/5/13

(28k loss) https://www.irs.gov/uac/Ten-Important-Facts-About-Capital-Gains-and-Losses If your total net capital loss is more than the yearly limit on capital loss deductions, you can carry over the unused part to the next year and treat it as if you incurred it in that next year.

http://www.bankrate.com/finance/taxes/capital-losses-can-help-cut-your-tax-bill.aspx Long-term losses are applied to long-term gains. The result, at the end of Part II of Form 8949, is the net long-term capital gain or loss. Again, if you have only a loss, then the net is a negative number. Next, you combine the short-term and long-term results on Schedule D. At this point, a loss in one section can offset a gain in the other section. For example, if you have a net short-term loss of $1,000 and a net long-term gain of $1,200, then you'll pay tax on only $200. If there's still a loss, you can deduct up to $3,000 from other income. If you had a really bad year and ended up with a net loss of more than $3,000, you can carry forward the leftover portion to next year's taxes. The unused loss can be applied to next year's gains, as well as up to $3,000 of earned income. A big loss can be used as a deduction indefinitely -- another important reason to keep good records. Read more: http://www.bankrate.com/finance/taxes/capital-losses-can-help-cut-your-tax-bill.aspx#ixzz3vy2xSQBe Follow us: @Bankrate on Twitter | Bankrate on Facebook

notes.note: I'm in a season of cutting out the noise. That means activities, accounts, and routines are all up for discussion. If I cannot justify a reasonable ROI then I cut it out. Over this past weekend I decided to delete my LinkedIn account. As a developer, my professional network is really about github. The primary purpose for user of linkedin is to gain assistance and exposure in their professional network. I admit it makes. - views matter - before after - how to videos - posted something relevant on LinkedIn - I got to meet and reconnect with old contacst because I was using my skills.
