February 17, 2009 Etta Wilson Books and Such Literary Agency 52 Mission Circle, Suite 122 PMB 170 Santa Rosa, CA 95409 Dear Ms. Wilson: You could say that JodiPo didn't quite fit in on her first day of school. When she walked into her new classroom balancing four books on her head wearing a grass skirt and a bark cape-coat made from trees near her native Papua New Guinea village her new American classmates were suspicious. But by the end of the week after JodiPo shared her colorful culture, ancient tribal traditions, and adventures as a missionary child the whole school's imagination was captivated! This 800-word picture book for ages five and up, follows a young girl's first day of school in an entirely new culture. Traveling around the world while attending Word of Life Bible Institute and Liberty University gave me insight into what it's like to come from a different culture. Although re-adjusting to a new culture can be a challenge, I learned about God's creative design and I think that a children's book about that experience would not only foster understanding and acceptance of different cultures, but it would be a celebration of those differences! I'm also a mother who longs for my children to learn the significance of God's unique design. My character, JodiPo, is based on my close friend and her life as a missionary child in Papua New Guinea. The purpose of this book is to teach children with engaging words, and expressive illustrations that because God created each of us differently we have reason to rejoice! Just like Peppe the Lamplighter, my book JodiPo Goes to School could be a cultural picture book. I see this book as a continuous series of stories about JodiPo's funny character building experiences adjusting to a new life in America. Although I do not have any writing credentials yet, I am excited and eager to start this process, and I would enjoy reading and speaking in school settings and talking with children about their own unique gifts and culture. I am not currently submitting this query to other agents because I wanted to give you an exclusive look first. Thank you for taking the time to consider representing my work. I look forward to hearing from you. Sincerely, Danae Woodall Danae Woodall 218 S. Downing St. Denver, CO. 80209 danaewoodall@gmail.com 303 862 7274

The purpose of this book is to teach children with engaging words, and expressive illustrations that because God created each of us differently we have reason to rejoice! Feb. 24, 2009 Expect to hear back by 3 months: JodiPo Goes to school JodiPo walked into her new classroom with a grass skirt on, a bark cape-coat, made from the trees in her village and four books balanced carefully on her head. “Good morning children!” Miss Peatriss said. “We have a new student starting today. Make her feel welcome as she is from a far away country called Papua New Guinea.” “I have a present for you Miss Peatriss,” JodiPo said. Miss Peatriss smiled and put out her hand. A garden snake slithered from JodiPo’s cape onto Miss Peatriss’s arm! “AHHHHH!! A SNAKE!!” Miss Peatriss screamed and the whole classroom jumped on their chairs screaming at the top of their lungs.the classroom gerbil did back flips in fear, and the boys screamed with the girls. JodiPo quickly grabbed the snake and took him outside to let him go. JodiPo explained to Miss Peatriss that in her village a snake is a welcome gift to a family. The garden snake will eat the rodents that run around the villagers’ huts. The classroom was struck with laughter. They had never seen such a different girl! “Where are you from - Mars?” Charlie yelled out. They laughed so hard in that instant that some snorted very loudly causing the classroom gerbil to hide. Miss Peatriss scorned her students and took away recess for the entire week. The students watched as JodiPo sat down in the front row and slowly removed the books from her head. JodiPo came from a place so far from this one; everything was new and different to her. Miss Peatriss apologized for her students’ behavior and told JodiPo that her recess was not taken away. At recess it started to rain. As the other kids ran for cover, JodiPo stomped into an ancient rain dance position. She clamped her hands together and began to sway back and forth humming a mystical thanksgiving to God for providing the rain. The students were astonished. They wanted to know all about where she came from. JodiPo began describing her home, and kids gathered in a circle around to listen to her stories. “My parents are missionaries. We lived in a hut near a rushing river in the tribe of Maprik. In Papua New Guinea there are small but deep pools of ocean water. I like to swim through the mysterious caverns in the pools,” she explained. JodiPo waved her hands in the air. "You don't want to get lost tramping through crocodile territory at night, so I learned how to use the stars as a map to navigate my way around." Her classmates curiously watched her from the window as she made new friends. The next day JodiPo wore a large red parrot feather hat and a bone necklace. Her classmates snickered at her. “Are you going to fly away with the feathers on your head?" Charlie jeered. JodiPo smiled at Charlie and handed him her necklace. “This is a white camel bone necklace made by the rare villagers of the east jungle,” JodiPo said. “I thought you might want it. It is a trophy of bravery.” “Oh. Thank you,” a surprised Charlie replied. At recess the students wanted to hear more of JodiPo's life on the island. JodiPo painted a colorful picture in their minds. The story started to come alive with her every sentence. It seemed they were on the island themselves. They tiptoed around quicksand and slid down a hidden waterfall off the Carcar trail. JodiPo's classmates watched and listened from behind the classroom window. This new girl was taking the entire elementary school on an adventure over recess without them! JodiPo’s classmates felt left out. They could hear drums in the distance, and they could smell the ocean. "We are very fortunate to have such a rare individual in our very own classroom," Miss Peatriss said. “Yeah, and we should all learn to dress just like JodiPo,” Charlie interrupted. He sat down and smiled at JodiPo. JodiPo’s classroom was especially colorful Monday morning. Some students were wearing tall feather hats, Some were wearing grass skirts. The gerbil was practicing his rain dance moves, and Charlie was wearing his new camel bone necklace and clumsily trying to balance four books on top of his head while giving JodiPo a thumbs up. “Good morning children!” Miss Peatriss greeted the class. “We have a new student starting today. Make him feel welcome. He is from a far away country called Scotland." Murdock walked into the classroom wearing a plaid kilt and a Glengarry cap on his head.
